replies.author: @dig8634
replies.text:
@2snowornot2know81 I like the inherent bias in saying "normal to far right people". Yeah, cause that isn't a skewed perspective to get a "consensus" from?
He clearly stated that he didn't know much about the topic, but gave his theory since he was asked about it. He didn't make a video about it like Sargon does when he is uninformed, it was just a comment made in passing. I know this was posted 2 years ago, but this seems like a really poor hot take on a comment that specifically mentioned it wasn't well informed.
It is quite the leap to equivocate an intentionally downplayed comment with the arrogance and overconfidence of youtubers like Sargon.

You mention gang crime as the perpetrators of gun violence, but that completely ignores that facet of gun crime most people are worried about, which is mass shootings. That is definitely an important facet of gun violence and it isn't perpetrated by gangs, but mostly white conservatives.
Another issue is police brutality that has come into extreme focus during this pandemic.

Even if we assume gang crime is the "cause" of gun violence, it is important to note that the readily available nature of guns in the US makes it easier for said gangs to get a hold of guns to be violent with. In too many states, guns can be purchased without any background checks. While the gun show loophole might be misnamed, it still is a loophole in the system that can be very easily abused to get your hands on a bunch of weapons you wouldn't usually be able to get.
Allowing private sellers to sell without going through the system, without checking the background of the buyer, means that any criminal can buy guns easily by just buying it through other people.

While closing the loophole wouldn't stop criminals from getting guns through smuggling or other illegal acts, it would still make it harder for criminals to get guns, since not all criminals have the connections needed for that, and it also allows the issue of criminals getting guns to be more efficiently targeted. There is no point in stopping gun smuggling if guns can just be purchased by anyone from random individuals, but if you do stop criminals from getting guns that way, stopping smuggling could actually have an effect on criminals getting guns.

Private sellers is a huge problem for gun crime, and gun control can stop that. Of course nobody is claiming that is gonna stop the entire problem, but we can't just ignore one facet of the problem just because there are other issues that ALSO need to be fixed. We'll never fix any problem if we allow other unrelated problems to be used as arguments against the solution.

author: @dannyarcher438
text:
hey Three Arrows, you misunderstood and therefore misrepresented the controversy of the Polish law. Israel and different Jewish communities appose that law because it also states you can not blame the "Polish people/nation" for crimes committed in Poland during the Nazi occupation.  a lot of Jews (ranging from a few hundreds to tens of thousands) were not only sold out but also killed directly by the local polish population, some for money and property and some just out of racism. killing of Jews by local poles ranges from pogroms during and after the war committed by whole villages to killings of hiding Jews or Jews that fled ghettos or camps by individual poles. many people fear this law is meant to hide these crimes and stop further discussion or research in the matter. NO one in his right mind  laims that concentration/death camps were polish.

also why are Germans worried about migrant/refugee anti antisemitism? there are basically no Jews in Germany these days.

replies.author: @pablopancho
replies.text: The truth is that this law was designed to stir up anti-German sentiments in Poland. Current goverment is heavily criticised by EU and many German officials so as a counter the ruling party PiS passed this law, raised up the question of war reparations etc. They used German tv channel ZDF's terrible gaffe as a reason. They didn't expect Israels reaction at all.  Meanwhile Israeli PM is engulfed in corruption scandal so he welcomed this distraction. Claims on all sides are exaggerated. Germans don't try to rewrite history and blame Poles for nazi death camps. The Polish law is not penalizing people who talk about pogroms or many other crimes or acts of anisemitism. It only intends to prevent assigning blame for actual German atrocities (ie death camps) to Polish nation. There is also a huge concern in Poland about not giving a fair picture of occupied country - it was a catastrophy and humanitarian disaster. There were people who in this catastrophy behaved despicably, others risk their life to safe the Jews, and here PiS has a point. And now the law is basically dead anyway.

replies.author: @doyleharken3477
replies.text: It's a cultural thing. Post-war German society was fiercely antifascist and that became anchored in our laws and institutions. So whenever anti-semitic sentiments show up, however mild, authorities react rather harshly.

Its obvious that most Poles did not like them and thats perfectly natural" so, you say they were of different religion, which of course they were they were Jews... what do you think Jew means? and therefore " Poles did not like them and thats perfectly natural" so you say its perfectly natural to hate Jews...OK then...

replies.author: @atropabelladonna
replies.text: Totally true. One of such cases is the pogrom in Jedwabne - it was described by a Polish-American historian Jan Gross in a book "Neighbors: The Destruction of the Jewish Community in Jedwabne, Poland". It cause Polish right-wingers to lose their shit and deny anything like this ever happened or claim that the Poles were forced by the Germans to commit this atrocity. I know a family friend who was born there after the war and she told us the story was one of this silent secrets that everyone there knew and no one wanted to talk about. Polish nationalists are more than keen to erase things like that from history (similarly to infamous invasion of Czechoslovakia to annex a small part of the border region, arm in arm with Hitler in 1938, which was both shameful and stupid). Nationalists do what they always do - whitewash their history and paint themselves as innocent victims surrounded by evil enemies and traitors.

author: @esthera3229
text: I am an American and a Social Libertarian/Liberal (economic centrist, socially libertarian), and as such I am very much pro-gun rights. However, I also realize that some regulation (mainly background checks, training licenses, and mandatory gun safes) are necessary. Ultimately, I subscribe the to Swiss take on the issue, with some minor differences. My question is, what do you think about Swiss gun laws? Do you think it's a good model universally? Or is it an anomaly and probably wouldn't work as well in other areas?

replies.author: @DrZaius3141
replies.text:
If you look at the stats, Switzerland may be a lot safer than the US, but they are still up there in the top nations in terms of gun possession and therefore gun violence. Although you are correct in using them as an example, because the culture around guns seems to be similar, i.e. the insane love for machines that only have the purpose of killing.

It really doesn't take anything out of common sense - you need a license to drive a car, you should need a license to own a gun. If you have any violent inclinations, you shouldn't be allowed a gun. That's just easy, and that part works in pretty much every country.

The aforementioned culture is a different aspect. If people don't want to own guns, the problem doesn't even come up. But that part won't change, neither in Switzerland nor in the US.

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text: A kill with a gun is the same as a kill with a knife, true (ie, the end result is a death). However, it's a lot easier to kill with a gun than with a knife to begin with, so it's a bit of a false equivalence.

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text: +Eli A - what does "socially libertarian" mean, and how does it differ from "socially liberal"?

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text: True, truck terrorism has been on the rise, but it's difficult to conceal a truck under your jacket, or to bring a truck into a school, or to hide a fleet of trucks in a cupboard, so the arena of trucks as a means of murder still remains rather limited. And even then, we actually do recognize trucks as a potentially dangerous tool, hence why most countries require people to take a truck driver's certification, and to register their truck ownership with the government. It's not perfect, but at least it weeds out some clearly incompetent people, and can make it easier to track down potential helpers in the case of a deliberate attack.

replies.author: @esthera3229
replies.text: I'm not disagreeing with background, mental health and proficiency checks. My problem is with gun bans. They are mostly ineffective and add unnecessary restrictions. Germany's gun laws are somewhat reasonable and I'm fine with them. Britain's complete gun ban is not something I'm a fan of, but its not my country. If we drew from the Swiss gun system by giving licenses for non-sporting-purpose firearms to reservists (2nd amendment refers to militias, and reservists are essentially more official militias) that'd be a good compromise.

replies.author: @esthera3229
replies.text: socially libertarian just means very socially liberal. Its essentially a step above but fundamentally the same. If you wanted to change it to socially liberal it wouldn't take much away from it, its just that social liberal these days tends to refer to neoliberals rather than my personal political ideology.

replies.author: @esthera3229
replies.text:
My point is that nations go  after the tools used to commit violence because that makes it look like they're looking out for the public, without actually trying to solve the core issues which cause crime and violence to exist. Its the equivalent of putting a couple band-aids on a 12 centimeter scar. Sure it MIGHT help, but you're still not doing much to solve the problem. 

Now the two aren't mutually exclusive, mind you, but solving crime at its core does more to help people than just restricting their freedoms

replies.author: @DrZaius3141
replies.text:
Yeah, it's easy to kill someone with a truck. That's why you need a license to drive one. Are there still people who drive one without a license? Sure thing, but it's a lot harder to use something you need a license for that you don't have.

Also: gun violence is the easiest violence there is. That's why it's the deadliest tool for suicides by far. People who want to commit suicide in a differen way are very likely to survive and after that not try again (cause it usually hurts and pain is a deterrent). People who want to commit suicide by gun usually succeed (if you can call it that).
Different situation: a fight between two spouses gets out of hands, someone goes for a weapon. It's either a) a knife - so the other one keeps their distance, maybe grab a chair to help with that, lock in a room and be really afraid, b) a gun - you're dead.
Somone wants to inflict a lot of pain on a lot of other people (i.e. school shootings). They take a car - people can evade. They take a knife - people can overpower them. They take a gun - people will die.

There is a reason why there is a huge correlation between gun ownership rates and gun violence. The violence when commited by guns is much more severe, much easier, much more accessible, much more effective. That's why sane cultures regulate them and require licenses, as well as background checks. No country really bans guns, but permits can vary in terms of how hard you might get them. And at the end of the day it's really simple: the easier it is to get guns, the more harm there is in a country. And if you spew the "if guns are outlawed, only outlaws have guns" BS at me, I refer you to the analogy of cars and licenses. Sure, you can use a car without a license, but it happens rather rarely.

author: @lavenderandred_
text:
Anarchism is a form of libertarian socialism. In a nutshell libertarian socialism is a school of socialism that rejects the state as a means of achieving communism. Other forms of libertarian socialism includes council communism and some forms of libertarian Marxism. This is opposed to forms of authoritarian socialism (such as Marxist-Leninism) that see the state as necessary to transfer to socialism. 

I hope this helped, I love your content and keep up the great work!

replies.author: @PristianoPenaldoSUIIII
replies.text: Lets Have A Discussion "anarchism as actually practised". For example....?

replies.author: @Returnofthenightguy
replies.text: Lets Have A Discussion No rulers not "no authority". If youve read a page of bakunin hes covered that in detail...150 years ago.

replies.author: @nakenmil
replies.text:
Regarding anarchism: Dictionary definition =/= Political definition.
(I'm not an anarchist myself, just pointing out that terms mean different things in different contexts)

replies.author: @edchaos2679
replies.text: AnCom_Tom I've personally never heard of a socialist libertarian. The libs are conservatives. Subscribing to the words of Ronald Reagan. They want less government but still want a centralized system with a hierarchy so I don't know how much anyone could associate that with Anarchism.

replies.author: @barkingnoise
replies.text:
+Ed Speanburgh
There's a pretty extensive wikipage on libertarian socialism
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libertarian_socialism
There's also a youtube-channel called "Libertarian Socialist Rants" which does a lot of videos, some detailing what libertarian socialism is. It reminds me at times of this channel actually

replies.author: @AndySomething
replies.text:
AnCom_Tom I'm probably a bit biased as an ancap but i'd disagree that anarchism necessarily means socialism. I'd say anarchism is the battle against authority and socialism is the battle against the trinity of usury - rent, interest and profit.

Although I'd agree with you that libertarian socialists all agree in rejecting the state as a means of forming a communist society; yet it's worth mentioning that not all libertarian socialists are communists.

replies.author: @Greg-sx9bb
replies.text: Anarchy at its core is anti hierarchy, not anti authority. There is a difference. Anarchists tend to believe in radical democracy, which excludes traditional ideas of the state. Anarcho-capitalism is a real thing, but its not technically anarchist.

replies.author: @AndySomething
replies.text:
Brosefman What about left wing market anarchists? They're socialists but dont believe in radical democracy like communists do. They're probably closer to some ancaps in most regards.

You might be right about ancapism not being anachism depending on the definition used; I've heard it described as radical liberalism which seems pretty accurate.

replies.author: @Greg-sx9bb
replies.text: Your point on anarcho capitalism is mostly right. The only issue is the idea of hierarchy structures (created by class and capital), which goes against the technical of anarchism. What your talking about with a market socialist anarchism sounds a lot like mutualism or the stuff Bakunin talked about. This is debatabke. I personally dont agree with it on all levels, but you can make a decent argument that it wouldnt create hierarchy.

replies.author: @Greg-sx9bb
replies.text: I definetly am open to discuss any forms of anti-hierarchy, as they at least see the core issue. I think anarcho-communism or syndicalism are more realistic though.

replies.author: @Greg-sx9bb

author: @julianmorrisco
text: Excellent, thank you for this. As with one of your commenters, I consider myself centrist although more recently this has started to mean soft-left. However, I do have concerns with the number of people immigrating to my country, the U.K., with Islamic beliefs. No, not terrorism,  very few are directly affected and the greatest danger is our response to it. Rather my concerns are with the issues of severe social conservatism and a disrespect for governance we have seen here. Things like the child sex-trafficking and several issues of political influence, including identitarian corruption at the local level that has started people talking for the first time about a requirement for ID when voting, amongst other more substantial changes. Although we do have plenty of Anglo-Saxon corruption it doesn‚Äôt tend to be based on religion or the country/region of origin of the corrupt or their parents, it is more about the lining of pockets. I don‚Äôt want to stop or even slow down immigration, particularly European or Indian immigration (Hindu anyway) as I believe it benefits the country and our economy will falter if it is ever tried. No, my concerns are about too many people from too conservative a culture with bad ideas I had naively thought had been or were being dealt with (particularly regarding women, homosexuals and Jews).  The recent flaring up of anti-semitism in the Labour Party here has a direct line to lefty criticism (justified) of Israel mixing with Islamic ideas and the old bigotry. This appalls me as I had hoped the Labour Party, which I vote for when not voting Green, would be a way to stop or minimise the Brexit bullshit but they are too busy playing the old trots vs Leninists vs stalinists vs social democrat game and fighting amongst themselves about whether criticism of Israel is anti-Semitic (it‚Äôs not) or whether criticism of the Zionist project is (it is, usually). However, since the surge in the right and particularly the nasty, anti-democratic right I am reluctant to raise any of my concerns due to my fear it empowers the authoritarian arseholes because of the complexity of the issue and their appealing to a large swathe of people with simple, tried and failed solutions from the far right. I also think the danger comes from them now. Still, Muslim immigration has been a great thing for this country but I have concerns about too much in too short a period of time. By the way, I agree with Frau Merkel‚Äôs refugee decision as an emergency measure but I do feel it was handled badly, for whatever reason including the number of people who took advantage of German compassion and generosity. And now it seems it will hurt other, future refugees when the next crisis turns up. Even if the immigrants themselves wish very much to integrate and most of them do, the current climate creates an ‚Äòus and them‚Äô dynamic which will drive increasing numbers of their children (it‚Äôs hardly ever the actual immigrants) to an extremist viewpoint. The great tragedy of Brexit is that it will mean increased immigration from the commonwealth (Pakistan, Nigeria and Bangladesh for example) to make up for the fewer Europeans coming here, which will only compound the problem. Business will get its workers from somewhere.  I suppose what I‚Äôm trying to say is that I‚Äôm not quite as sanguine about the type of immigration we have as you are. This is very difficult and I particularly want to stress that I do not hold negative views about anybody based on their religious belief, beyond a certain suspicion as to the rational behaviour of anyone who believes in supernatural beings and events, but I am concerned about too many people in too short a period of time with beliefs that are too socially conservative. This aside, I agree almost completely with what I have discerned of your viewpoint, and I consider this one disagreement secondary, if related, to the rise of the authoritarians and nativists.

author: @dnys_7827
text:
for an introduction to anarchism, I would recommend George Woodcock's Socialism from Below and Rudolf Rocker's Anarcho-syndicalism. Both books offer historical insights into the anarchist movement and some well phrased explanations of anarchist political thought. also, since you're German, you can read rocker in the original German. 
Emma Goldman's essays are valuable in that they offer a broad ( if slightly aged ) look at the many areas of life to which anarchism as a mode of thought and action can be applied. Her book Anarchism and Other Essays is very interesting in that regard.

author: @glorytotheaprdeathtotheufl7917
text: Libertarian socialism are socialism models that are generally focused on having a community organisation or another bottom-up-model (think syndicalism, anarchism, council communism etc.) Prominent figures are people like George Orwell, Rosa Luxemburg, all anarchists, the IWW, Noam Chomsky, (you also could say that Zizek, Dubcek and Albert Einstein were libertarian socialists too)

I find that useful information to the seeker, generally, if the interest is in understanding language and social dynamics.

author: @deathpigeon2
text: Libertarian socialist is typically a euphemistic way of saying "anarchist" and has been used frequently by anarchists in places where speaking about anarchism is banned, but it also gets used to describe anarchist adjacent politics, so people like Oscar Wilde who saw a place for the state in society, but thought it would have an extremely limited role therein, or people like Bookchin who was opposed to the state, but opposed anarchistic praxis in favor of more of a focus on local electoral politics, so it's more broad than anarchist, but, in most cases, when someone talks of libertarian socialists, they're talking specifically about anarchists.

author: @gnetkuji
text: About you pointing out that there is severe academic discourse over the 1932/33 famine:  Fair enough.  I didn't dislike your debunking video because the rest of it was so good, but it did bother me greatly that you drew an equivalence between a fiercely debated academic question and literal holocaust deniers, which is, itself, another deflection tactic used by neo-nazis.  "Well, if you think my questioning the holocaust is so absurd, why don't you spend your time attacking the commies for murdering fifty bajillion more than hitler instead?"  Seeing you so casually concede to it was immensely upsetting.  I don't ask you to change your opinion on the famine, just *please* do not give nazis the legitimacy they seek by placing their denial on the same level as a legitimate academic debate.

author: @forzainuu6051
text: I thought Germany didn¬¥t have a constitution (verfassung) and was still use the basic law. Have it changed and if so what are the mayor differences between the constitution and the basic law?

replies.author: @fermintenava
replies.text:
The "basic law" (I think you mean the "Grundgesetz"?) IS in fact our constitution. Until 1990, it was the constitution for West Germany (BRD), while East Germany (DDR) had its own constitution, and the BRD postulated its as a partial constitution until the reunification with the East. With the reunification in 1990, it became the official constitution of all of Germany and was recognized as such by the allies.
Also, all federal states have their own accordant state constitutions.

author: @Dragons_Armory
text:
Generation war, good series, I actually really liked the younger brother's journey, I find it really interesting he went from seen as a pacifist or an inept soldier to be a steely eyed fatalistic killing machine. I also feel that he "got" the war more than his older brother did, even though he was not the level as his older brother in terms of adopting to military culture he was always aware of the consequences, even before he died. 

I liked all the character's stories except perhaps that of the actress girl played by Katharina Sch√ºttler. I feel her story is a little too convenient in the sense that its all about her selling herself for one Jewish friend. Not saying that there weren't good selfless people like that, I'm sure there were a good number of such silent minority, but I just feel its less powerful and less related to the plot than the other 3 characters. I also feel that the media wants the audiences to zero in on her despite the...well, holocaust that's happening all around. Though I will admit that her rise in fame and fall does show the nasty abusive side of the Reich to its own (even well off) citizendry. 

Personally I wouldn't mind a perspective from a disgruntled and disillusioned WW1 soldier or an utterly impoverished child who grow up to be a full blown Nazi ideologue if anything to see from his perspective how someone like that gets to become that way (an...Star Wars Empire's perspective from the other side so to say) how someone lonely and powerless comfortably becomes part of a marching army toward death. Though I might be projecting here.

author: @sofia.eris.bauhaus
text:
you really think that that the grundgesetz can prevent fascism?

the verfassungsgericht (constitutional court) can topple some particularly authoritarian laws sometimes (like data retention/vorratsdatenspecherung), but then the same laws just get reinstituted again and again until they stick. 

and frankly there seems to be so much self-weakening and backpaddling in the grundgesetz like this:

2.2: Every person shall have the right to life and physical integrity. [yes, very good]
Freedom of the person shall be inviolable. [vague, but ambitious!]
These rights may be interfered with only pursuant to a law. [are you EFFIN KIDDING ME?]

so basically we could have torture law and a death penalty law and then article 2.2 would become meaningless..

and there are broad caveats for about every basic human right.

and while there is an eternity clause to protect the first 20 articles, that clause does not protect itself, and so a fascist government would probably just remove that clause first..

so yeah, i don't see how any law can really prevent fascism, and i can certainly imagine a much more liberal and anti-fascist constitution..

author: @PizzaRollExpert
text:
So I have to say, I'm really annoyed at the way people talk about free will and determinism. People often take for granted that they are incompatible with each other, but if you look at the discourse surrounding it within philosophy you find that the most popular position among philosophers is actually what is known as compatibilism, which basically just means that free will and determinism are compatible. 

Part of the reason why people are, in my opinion, so bad at discussing this is that this question comes from a time when we viewed the world quite differently. The question "do we have free will?" then meant something along the lines "are we able to rebel against our fate?". Today people substitute fate with determinism but it's not exactly the same thing and the question breaks down a bit as a result of this.

I can recommend reading Daniel Dennett's review of Free Will if you are interested in learning more about the compatibilist position. It does not presuppose any training in philosophy so it should be fairly approachable: https://samharris.org/reflections-on-free-will/

replies.author: @DeoMachina
replies.text:
Yeah but if you look into philosophy, you also find that people still think the name Anselm of Cantebury is worth writing down and his ideas are actually worthwhile, instead of vapid discharge that dampens the intellect of anybody who considers them.
What I'm trying to say is, fuck what a bunch of book merchants have to say on the topic.  Fuck Harris and Dennett.  The definitions of free will and determinism ARE mutually exclusive.  They're designed to be.

author: @skeletony9156
text:
I've needed a channel like this to provide an alternative perspective. So far its been mind numbing lefty media and alt-media channels like Sargon of Akkad, so I've just grown to hate the left and identify hugely with the right as a liberal. While I completely support your historical corrections, you haven't convinced me on your politics, but I'll try (as always) to have an open mind.

It seems to me like you just downplay the issues that the right and I find significant and ignore the problems we see in the left, especially in the US, but you've haven't made many videos so I'll give you time. While I don't believe in an Alex Jones-like conspiracies about the Marxist at the gates, I see all extremist movements on the left and right as threatening and should be combated by moderates of all stripes.

replies.author: @DeoMachina
replies.text:
Here's the thing mr Skelebones:
There...isn't a left.  Not really.  Who has the USA got on the left?  Bernie Sanders?  That's it?  Is a desire for basic healthcare and democracy all it takes to be left-wing now?  Those *should* be conservative values.

So when you say you hate the left..who are you even referring to?  That's the real problem I think we have, most of the hatred of the left is directed at people and organisations which *do not exist.*  And that's why calling them out tends not to happen.

replies.author: @skeletony9156
replies.text:
While I agree that the left is disorganised and isn't aptly represented by the Democrats in the US (though I would argue that few are aptly represented in a FPTP, two party system), I definitely can see that there is a left, however disjointed and confused it may be. I see it in the widely anti-trump American media, such as CNN and all the various today/tonight/late shows. I see it in Antifa running in the streets punching "nazis". I see it in the SJW's who are indoctrinating students in Universities with bullshit courses like gender studies. I see it in Labour, who are steadily gaining popularity here in the UK, especially amongst the youth. I see it in brain dead journalism publishers like Buzzfeed, Vox, Vice and The Guardian, though I'd expect Three Arrows to disregard them as nothing more than clickbaiting companies which is fair enough.

Your response does hint at the big problem in today's western society's, that being people refusing to step outside their echo chambers in order to really try to understand the other side's argument, instead of twisting it into something that it isn't to make it easily refutable. That's exactly why I'm on this channel, trying to understand the other perspective.

replies.author: @DeoMachina
replies.text:
CNN and the late night shows are hardly left-wing.  Do you know how long it took for them to even give Bernie a look-in?  Anti-Trump sure, anybody with a conscience has to be.  But there's plenty of conservatives who hate him too, that's why his approval polls have always been so low.

I'm not sure antifa really qualify as left-wing, I don't doubt they have leftists in their midst, but punching nazis is literally a matter of self-preservation for everybody who isn't a nazi.  I'm not exaggarating, that is 100% serious.  So really, it could be anybody who punched Richard Spencer, I don't know.  They don't really have political positions, they're not even a 'group' really.

As for SJW's in universities..that's over-exaggarated.  Students have been doing dumb, radical shit for decades and decades now.  Stunts, protests, you name it.  You can't write off everything you don't like as being left-wing though.  Some people think philosophy is bullshit indoctinration, but it's not political.  Same with gender studies, it's not really left-wing, unless you define right-wing as "opposing any evaluation of gender-based power structures within society".

Labour...have spent the past 20 years copying Tory policy.  That's the opposite of what left-wing means.  Yes, they have Corbyn now, but that hasn't stopped them from siding with the Tories in so many bills.

I honestly don't read any of those publishers, so maybe they are legitimately leftist?  We can't deny that print media is hugely biased towards the right though.

replies.author: @skeletony9156
replies.text:
Ok I cba to make a response to that block of text. Rest assured that we are still in disagreement about all of the talking points in this little discussion but I won't try to change your mind.

Edit: All except for the left being disorganised I guess, though it's not like the right is entirely united either. Don't let that Unite the Right tiki torch march fiaso from a couple months back fool you, liberals like I don't associate with the alt-right.

replies.author: @DrZaius3141
replies.text: "anti-Israel"... Dude, when your country doesn't have a right-wing nutjob in power, you Israel is supported by every side. It's only when they start to attack their neighbours to the tunes of their propaganda machinery that the rest of the world looks at them and goes: "Really?"

replies.text:
DrZaius3141 
Israel attacks terrorists, they don't just attack countries around for the funs of it.

replies.author: @dannyarcher438
replies.text:
its not about history or context... its about living in an area that works by different rules than European. 
you can read the history and know the context of the soviet union, but will you be able to understand whats it like in a communist country? whats it like really? i doubt it.
i wasn't born in Israel and i study in a different continent now. but my mom is Israeli and i lived there for 5 years, 3 of which i was in the army.

replies.text:
David Archer 
Wow, thank you for your service, I assume that you volunteered?

And I agree with you that they won't understand how it is, but I don't think that you have to understand everything in order to support israel, I just think that a lot of people are misinformed.

It does seem that europeans lack the understanding of what the majority of muslims are like, three arrows for example doesn't seem too worried about the immigration to Europe at all.

David Archer 
I think that I should clarify: when I say the majority of muslims I mean the majority of muslims thag were raised in Islamic countries.

author: @gurkenhamster
text: Honestly, characterising the EU as Germany's fourth reich is not so far off, and definitely not exclusively a right wing position. As a german, you'll probably remember Sarah Wagenkencht's characterization of the EU as "neoliberal, undemocratic, and militaristic", and while I disagree with her on many other issues (her reactonary stance towards immigration, and her wishy-washy embracing of social market-economy as a form of socialism instead of owning it and being a proper communist), she was most definitely right on that point. Many leftists in the UK supported Brexit as well, the Socialist Party (CWI) being one of them. Then again, I'm not surprised by your view, since from your channel-name and symbol I'm guessing you're anti-communist - the "Eiserne Front" had a starkly anti-KPD position after all.
